reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Bovine Tuberculosis and Brucellosis Subject Matter Expert for Workshop

description.narrative: Support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade.

This award strives to support the science and practice of food, feed, and fiber production (including forestry, wildlife, fisheries, aquaculture and floriculture) and its relationships to natural resources, processing, marketing, distribution, utilization (including nutrition), and trade. In addition, this award From April 10-13, 2016, APHIS IS Participated in the ‘Priority Zoonotic and Animal Disease Recognition and Response’ Workshop in Georgetown Guyana. The University of the West Indies, through its European Union funded “One Health, One Caribbean, One Love” project, and the Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture (IICA), through its European Union funded Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) project, organized the third in a series of national training workshops aimed at training the Guyana Veterinary Services and selected livestock producers on ‘Priority Zoonotic and Animal Disease Recognition and Response’. Dr. Alejandro Perera (APHIS IS – Mexico) participated presenting 2 topics: 1) Bovine Tuberculosis (TB) and 2) Brucellosis (BR). APHIS participation focused on providing information on bovine TB/BR programs in cattle populations and the potential impact in human populations..

participating-org.usg:office-name: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: Guyana's economic growth, resulting from the expansion of its mining sectors, has not resulted in improved social and political development indicators. Challenges to Guyana's development persist, including weak infrastructure, deficiencies in its anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing regime, persistent crime, limited law enforcement capacity, drug trafficking, continued out-migration, and the ongoing threat from the HIV/AIDS epidemic. U.S. assistance to Guyana focuses on strengthening democratic institutions, improving citizen security, combatting illicit trafficking, and mitigating the impact of the HIV/AIDS epidemic through the promotion of local, sustainable country programs. Regional programs will advance citizen security through the Caribbean Basin Security Initiative in order to complement and enhance U.S. bilateral assistance.

usg:treasury-account.usg:main-account: Salaries and Expenses, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agriculture
